maml:description.maml:para: Backup an Exchange server to a Data Domain storage host, using ProtectPoint or block based backup technology.
The Backup-Exchange cmdlet backs up an Exchange installation. Backups are created on Data Domain hosts using RecoverPoint, VMAX, or block based backup technology.
The local database, or databases, and Exchange server are automatically identified. The destination storage host and directory on that host must be identified by command parameters.
Progress is reported at a coarse level.
Specifies the client name to use for indexing the backup.
Specifies the Data Domain host names. For non-VMAX configurations, this must be a single name. For supported VMAX configurations, this can contain multiple names.

Specifies the path on the Data Domain host for the backup. The Data Domain user must have appropriate access rights for this path. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Specifies the Data Domain user. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Full credentials are retrieved from the LockBox to authenticate with the host.
Runs the command as a background job. Use this parameter to run the backup in the background.

When you use AsJob, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use Receive-Job.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs and about_Remote_Jobs.
When backing up a Database Availability Group, backup active databases.
When backing up a Database Availability Group, backup passive databases.
When backing up a Database Availability Group, backup preferred databases.

Specifies the Data Domain VDisk user. If not specified, defaults to the DataDomainUser. If specified, this must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Full credentials are retrieved from the LockBox to authenticate with the host.
Set the debug level for the child process.

Specifies which debug log files will be deleted according to the age in days. All of the (backup/restore) debug logs older than the specified number of days will be deleted. If the value is not specified then the functionality will be disabled. The specified value must be between 1 to 32767.
The path to the application program executable. This should not normally be used; instead, the cmdlet will automatically locate the installed application.
The list of database identities to back up. If not specified or empty, all databases are backed up.
When backing up a Database Availability Group, backup stand-alone databases.

Contains details of the backup.
Attributes:
ExchangeVersion: The Exchange version backed up.
BackupDateTimeUTC: The backup date and time, in Universal time.
BackupDatabases: An array containing an ExchangeBackupDataBase objects for each database included in the backup.
Level: The backup level.
BackupID: The backup ID.
Successful: $true if the backup was successful.
ClientName: THe client name, or host, of the backup.
DataDomainHost: The Data Domain host containing the backup.
DataDomainHostPath: The path to the backup on the Data Domain host.

maml:alert.maml:para: RecoverPoint performs backups not of files or drives but of consistency groups, which are sets of logical units (volumes). When requesting a backup of an Exchange server, or of individual databases, the backup created is actually of the consistency group.
As such, all other databases and any other non-Exchange data on the volumes within the consistency group will also be backed up in the RecoverPoint snapshot.

VMAX performs backups not of files or drives but of physical devices (LUNs). When requesting a backup of an Exchange server, or of individual databases, the backup created is actually the entire contents all volumes on the physical devices.
As such, all other databases and any other non-Exchange data on the volumes on the physical devices will also be backed up in the VMAX snapshot.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Perform a backup of Exchange to the Data Domain host ddserver.myorg.com in the directory path /ddbmda/myorg using block based backup. The Data Domain user is dd_user. The client name is the application host's canonical name.

Perform a backup of Exchange to the Data Domain host ddserver.myorg.com in the directory path /ddbmda/myorg using block based backup. The Data Domain user is dd_user. The client name is the application host's canonical name. Retention time is 40days.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets Exchange backups from a Data Domain storage host.
The Get-ExchangeBackup cmdlet gets backup information for Exchange host backups from a Data Domain host.
The Data Domain host is queried for backups of the Exchange host; the backups retrieved can be limited by date or to a specific number of newest backups.
The output object can be piped to the Restore-ExchangeBackup to restore the backups.

Specifies the path on the Data Domain host for the backup. The Data Domain user must have appropriate access rights for this path. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Specifies the Data Domain user. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Full credentials are retrieved from the LockBox to authenticate with the host.
Specify the latest date to get. If not provided, all backups are included.

maml:alert.maml:para: If the backup is made with block based backup technology, a tray icon appears which can be used to manipulate the mounts.
By default, backups are automatically dismounted after 8 hours. Also, a backup will unmount if the host is rebooted.

Backup mounts made with block based backup technology cannot be retrieved or dismounted by using the Get-ExchangeBackupMount and Dismount-ExchangeBackupMount cmdlets. These mounts must be viewed and dismounted by using the tray icon.

Mounts of backups made with ProtectPoint technology, such as RecoverPoint or VMAX, will persist until explicitly dismounted using the Dismount-ExchangeBackupMount cmdlet. These backups will stay mounted when the host is rebooted.

command:example.maml:title: ---------- EXAMPLE 1 ----------
command:example.dev:code: Get-ExchangeBackup -DataDomainHost ddserver.myorg.com -DataDomainUser dd_user -Limit 1 -DataDomainPath /ddbmda/myorg -ClientName ([System.Net.DNS]::GetHostByName('').HostName) | Mount-ExchangeBackup -RestoreDevicePool dd_recov_pool -RestoreDeviceGroup dd_recov_group

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the most recent backup of this host, and mount all databases in the backup. The backup is on the Data Domain server ddserver.myorg.com in the server directory /ddbmda/myorg. The Data Domain user is dd_user. The system's canonical name is used for the client name. The local Data Domain recovery device is in the pool dd_recov_pool and group dd_recov_group.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes one or more backups of an Exchange installation.
The Remove-ExchangeBackup removes backups of an Exchange Server installation created with Backup-Exchange.
The backup to remove.
Specifies the client name to use for indexing the backup.
Specifies the Data Domain host names. For non-VMAX configurations, this must be a single name. For supported VMAX configurations, this can contain multiple names.

Specifies the path on the Data Domain host for the backup. The Data Domain user must have appropriate access rights for this path. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Specifies the Data Domain user. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Full credentials are retrieved from the LockBox to authenticate with the host.
Runs the command as a background job. Use this parameter to run the backup in the background.

When you use AsJob, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use Receive-Job.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs and about_Remote_Jobs.

Specifies the Data Domain VDisk user. If not specified, defaults to the DataDomainUser. If specified, this must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Full credentials are retrieved from the LockBox to authenticate with the host.
Set the debug level for the child process.
The path to the application program executable. This should not normally be used; instead, the cmdlet will automatically locate the installed application.
Specifies whether to ignore failures when deleting backups and associated information; when enabled, the delete operation will report the failure and continue with the next item.
When used with -AsJob, specifies a friendly name for the job. You can use the name to identify the job to other job cmdlets, such as Stop-Job.
Ignored if -AsJob is not also specified.
If not supplied, the job will have no name.
Specifies the path to the LockBox. If not specified, the installation default is used.
Increase the amount of -Verbose output.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get all backups older than 7 days of this host and remove them. The backup is on the Data Domain server ddserver.myorg.com in the server directory /ddbmda/myorg. The Data Domainuser is dd_user. The system's canonical name is used for the client name.

maml:description.maml:para: Restores one or more databases to an Exchange installation.
The Restore-ExchangeBackup cmdlet restores databases to Exchange installation from backups created by Backup-Exchange.
The local Exchange server is automatically identified unless the -ExchangeServer parameter is supplied.
The backup, or database backup IDs from a single backup, to restore. This must be either a single ID or match each database provided in the -Identity list.
Specifies the client name to use for indexing the backup.
Specifies the Data Domain host names. For non-VMAX configurations, this must be a single name. For supported VMAX configurations, this can contain multiple names.

Specifies the path on the Data Domain host for the backup. The Data Domain user must have appropriate access rights for this path. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Specifies the Data Domain user. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Full credentials are retrieved from the LockBox to authenticate with the host.
Select a normal restore. This will restore the databases selected from the backup.
Runs the command as a background job. Use this parameter to run the backup in the background.

When you use AsJob, the command returns an object that represents the job, and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use Receive-Job.
For more information about Windows PowerShell background jobs, see about_Jobs and about_Remote_Jobs.
For restores from backups made with block based backup technology, specifies the Data Domain Fibre Channel host name. Ignored for restores from backups made with other technologies.

Specifies the Data Domain VDisk user. If not specified, defaults to the DataDomainUser. If specified, this must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Full credentials are retrieved from the LockBox to authenticate with the host.
Set the debug level for the child process.

Specifies which debug log files will be deleted according to the age in days. All of the (backup/restore) debug logs older than the specified number of days will be deleted. If the value is not specified then the functionality will be disabled. The specified value must be between 1 to 32767.
The eCDM host. If both eCDM host and eCDM user are specified, the restore operation will use the eCDM appliance to access the backup images.
The eCDM diagnostic log level. This is optional for eCDM restores, and is ignored for other restores. If omitted, a default value is used.
The eCDM diagnostic log tag. This is optional for eCDM restores, and is ignored for other restores. If omitted, a default value is used.
The eCDM mount timeout, in minutes. This is optional for eCDM restores, and is ignored for other restores. If omitted, a default value is used.
The eCDM communication port. This is optional for eCDM restores, and is ignored for other restores.
The eCDM Tenant. This must be supplied for eCDM restores.
The eCDM User. If both eCDM host and eCDM user are specified, the restore operation will use the eCDM appliance to access the backup images.
The name of the Exchange server to restore, if different than the local host's name. This defaults to the host portion of the -ClientName parameter.
When specified, the client name provided is used as-is, rather than being converted to the fully qualified DNS host name.
The path to the application program executable. This should not normally be used; instead, the cmdlet will automatically locate the installed application.
The database(s) to restore from the backup named in -BackupID or provided to -Backup.
When used with -AsJob, specifies a friendly name for the job. You can use the name to identify the job to other job cmdlets, such as Stop-Job.
Ignored if -AsJob is not also specified.
If not supplied, the job will have no name.
Specifies the path to the LockBox. If not specified, the installation default is used.
Override the group name for static images in the backup.
Override the pool name for static images in the backup.
Do a point-in-time restore. This is the default for -NormalRestore.
The Data Domain recovery device group.
The Data Domain recovery device pool.

For VMAX rollback restores, prefer to restore from the Data Domain. For eCDM normal restores and mounts, mount or restore directly from the Data Domain using RDM VDisk devices to mount; do not communicate with the eCDM appliance. Ignored for non-VMAX and non-eCDM operations.
Increase the amount of -Verbose output.
The backup to restore. This is limited to a single backup; all databases in the backup will be restored unless restricted by the -Identity parameter.
Contains details of the backup.
Attributes:
ExchangeVersion: The Exchange version backed up.
BackupDateTimeUTC: The backup date and time, in Universal time.
BackupDatabases: An array containing an ExchangeBackupDataBase objects for each database included in the backup.
Level: The backup level.
BackupID: The backup ID.
Successful: $true if the backup was successful.
ClientName: THe client name, or host, of the backup.
DataDomainHost: The Data Domain host containing the backup.
DataDomainHostPath: The path to the backup on the Data Domain host.
Specifies the client name to use for indexing the backup.
Specifies the Data Domain host names. For non-VMAX configurations, this must be a single name. For supported VMAX configurations, this can contain multiple names.

Specifies the path on the Data Domain host for the backup. The Data Domain user must have appropriate access rights for this path. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.
Specifies the Data Domain user. This must either be a single item or have the same number of entries as DataDomainHost. When it is a single item, it is used for all Data Domain hosts.

maml:alert.maml:para: When doing a Rollback Restore, RecoverPoint version 5 and later restores not files or drives but logical units (physical devices). All data on all the volumes on the physical devices selected will be restored.

RecoverPoint version 4 and earlier restores consistency groups instead of files or drives. Consistency groups are sets of logical units (physical devices). All data on all the volumes on the physical devices contained in the consistency group select will be restored.

RecoverPoint version 4 and earlier will not allow attempts to restore individual databases from a backup when performing a rollback restore. The restore operation will be unable to restore any data and will report a failure.
When performing a Rollback Restore, VMAX restores logical units (physical devices) instead of files or drives. All data on all the volumes on the physical devices selected will be restored.
Backups made with block based backup technology cannot be restored through a Rollback Restore operation. Only Copy Restore or Normal Restore operations are supported.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Get the most recent backup of this host, and restore it using the rollback (LUN level) restore. The backup is on the Data Domain server ddserver.myorg.com in the server directory /ddbmda/myorg. The Data Domain user is dd_user. The system's canonical name is used for the client name.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Using server information that has been imported by Import-ExchangeBackupConfigFile into $serverinfo, dismount all active mounts.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets a list of local active Exchange Server backup mounts.
